Concerns Voiced At
Student Convocation
by Mark Hsu
Prior to his formal installation
as Johns Hopkins' eleventh president today, William Richardson
addressed the students in a convocation Wednesday at Shriver
Hall, in which he called his introductory period "very rewarding" and expressed his hopes of
maintaining "the seriousness of
intent and the cordial atmosphere" at the University.
As co-chair of the Graduate
Representative Organization,
Greg Fieldson began the convocation with a presentation of
"the interests and hopes of
graduate students." He noted that
there were some imminent problems in doctoral programs
across the United States: a decline
in the quality of students, an increase in the time needed to complete the education, and a high attrition rate. Fieldson conceded
that while Hopkins is not immune
,to these problems, he cited
Richardson's commitment to
graduate students and his willingness to address graduate concerns. "One of Hopkins' best
strengtM is William Richardson," he said.
Philip Hale, president of the
Peabody Students Association,

thanked

Conservatory, his fund-raising,
and creating a positive working
experience." In addition, Hale
presented an autographed portrait
of concert pianist Arthur Rubenstein to Richardson.

Representing the undergraduate body, President
Bob Nelson of the Student Council was particularly impressed
with Richardson's efforts to actively meet students, including
the invitation of Orientation
leaders to his home for dinner and
his attendance at Hopkins basketball games. Speaking about the
changes that should be made in
the future, Nelson said, "I hope
that the undergraduate students
have more input on school affairs, anything from modifications of the curriculum, the Student Union, campus housing, and
graduation requirements."
Two other problems mentioned by Nelson were the expanded enrollment and the
decrease of the faculty, as well as
security on campus in terms of
lighting and the shuttle bus. At
the end of his speech, he and
Fieldson presented Richardson
with a framed aerial photo of the
Homewood campus.

described a letter he had
received from two high school
students from Pennsylvania who

classes and talking to students. In
comparison to three other
prestigious colleges they also
visited, the students wrote that
they were most impressed with

"The United States policy has
always been one of divide and
rule," said columnist Christopher
Hitchens of The Nation in a talk
on the current crisis in the Middle East last Friday. "Divide et
impera, the playing off of one
against another, and both ends
against the middle."
Hitchens' column "The
Minority Report" appears twice
a month in The Nation, a wellknown leftist weekly journal. Invited to speak in the Garrett
Room of the MSE library by the
Middle Eastern Students Association and the Graduate Students for
Social Responsibility, Hitchens
offered his own analysis of the
history of the Gulf region leading
up to the present war and of the
policy goals of the U.S. for the
region.
Hitchens repeatedly emphasized that he was "neither a conspiracy theorist nor paranoid," in
arguing the case that the U.S.
policy is tantamount to imperialism, noting with care his
sources of information on which
he based his views. While
arguably taking the position of a
dispassionate observer, he
nevertheless availed himopportuniself of the
ty to make sardonic remarks and
quips about the past four United
States presidents and their administrations, much to the delight
of the audience.
Some in the audience,
however, were visibly shocked
when Hitchens reserved his
harshest criticism for the leaders
of the peace movement, calling
their alleged concern about the
potential for U.S. casualties
moronic and naive. The audience
was composed mainly of war protesters, many of whom were
middle-aged. A lengthy question
and answer session, punctuated
by disruptions by supporters of
extremist Lyndon Larouche,
followed the talk in which Hit-

chens discussed his differences
with members of the peace
movement.

said Hitchens in beginning his

conflict.
The border was drawn up by an

1922, according to Hitchens. The
design was "to deny the

"This decision was backed up

because troops were scarce after
the first World War, it was decided that the only way to govern
[Iraq] was by imposing rule from
the sky, another tricky business."

The Defense Department plans
to reduce the number of Reserve
Officer Training Corps scholarships by 20 percent, starting this
fall.
The cuts are part of a larger
Defense Department plan to
reduce the number of people in
the armed services. After watching economic and political
reforms sweep Eastern Europe,
Congress cut the Defense Department's budget last year, and
department officials ordered all
the services to reduce their
personnel.
The R.O.T.C. numbers were
set before war broke out in the
Middle East. Pentagon officials,
who expect the war to be short,
say the cuts will either take effect
as planned or be postponed for
only a short time.
The Defense Department said
the Army, Air Force, and Navy
R.O.T.C. programs would not be
affected equally by the cuts,
which are to be completed within
five years. Each of the three services is now devising its own plan
for reductions. Students who
want to join the Marine Corps
enlist in the Navy R.O.T.C.
program.
Many students see R.O.T.C. as
an attractive way to pay for college. Students must compete for
R.O.T.C. scholarships, which
are offered for one to four years
and cover the cost of tuition and
fees. The program also pays for
books and provides a stipend of
$100 a month for each student.
After graduation, cadets are offered an officer's commission and
must serve for at least three years.
Following are the reductions
planned so far:
• The Air Force will drop the
number of new R.O.T.C.
scholarships for academic
1991-92 from 2,100 to 1,900.

The Air Force now has 16,167
cadets at the nation's colleges and
universities.
• The Navy will cut the number
of new R.O.T.C. scholarships by
15 per cent by 1994, according
to Gregory Stallworth, a
spokesman for the Chief of Naval
Education and Training Office.
Currently, 8,783 students are in
the naval R.O.T.C. program.
The Navy offered 1,708 new
scholarships in 1990, down from
1,920 in 1989. The Navy will
also close R.O.T.C. programs at
five universities and combine 16
other programs into eight
"geographic consortia" in 1996.
The programs to be closed are
Texas Tech University and the
Universities of Minnesota,
Missouri, New Mexico, and
Utah.
•The Army will cut the number
of new R.O.T.C. scholarships by
3 percent next year, according to
Maj. Robert Shepherd, a
spokesman for the army
R.O.T.C. The Army offered
3,028 new scholarships in
academic year 1990-91, but will
offer only 1,830 in academic
1991-92. Major Shepherd said
the decrease was in part the result
of a plan to award more four-year
scholarships, instead of the twoyear scholarships that have been
offered in the past.
The scholarship cuts contribute
to the uncertainty that has surrounded the R.O.T.C. programs
for the last several months.
Last summer, Army officials
announced they would close 50 of
the 413 Army R.O.T.C. units at
colleges and universities as part
of cutbacks in the military
budget.
In addition, students and faculty members at several colleges
and universities want R.O.T.C.
programs banned from campuses
because the military services

Shoveling through the Mail
Through the years, and particularly during this year, the NewsLetter has received hundreds of thoughtful, often provocative letters. Their missions are various: some take a stand on campus issues;
some respond to opinion pieces or other letters; some warn of growing conspiracies in American politics; and others, rare though they
are, take the News-Letter to task for its journalistic practices. The
News-Letter reads this last group with intense interest and sincere
concern. Like most publications, we rely upon our readers to bring
things to our attention that slip through editorial cracks: evidence
of racism or sexism, misquotes or incorrect attribution of quotes,
editorializing in stories, pertinent isues that repeatedly fail to receive
coverage in our pages—the list is potentially infinite. Although errors inevitably do wriggle their way into each issue, the News-Letter
tries assiduously each week to publish a paper that fairly represents
both life at Johns Hopkins and the concerns of the Hopkins Community. Thus we are grateful for these corrections and clarifications;
they remind us that every story has unexplored angles, issues that
do not automatically float to the surface.
Sometimes, however, the News-Letter hears from readers who have
more sweeping accusations to make. Their letters might accuse us
of doing damage to the University's reputation—or perhaps to an individual's—or of intentionally burying stories that the Hopkins Community has a right to know about. These are seious accusations, stabs
that call into question everything that the News-Letter requires to
operate successfully—the trust of its readers and the belief that the
paper serves an important function. Recently, three such complaints
have been leveled at the News-Letter, two in letters to the editors
and one in a commentary printed in the Hopkins Spectator. Each
deserves a response.
'Misquoting'—In the February 15 issue of the News-Letter, there
appeared a letter to the editors by Craig Freeman, who accused staff
reporter Harry Milling of "severely misquoting" him in a February
8 article about Phi Mu's opportunity to move into Rogers House.
The quotation at issue was Freeman's statement that some administrators believed that "a fraternity's occupation of Rogers House
might not 'run as smoothly' as a sorority's occupation might." This,
Freeman said, "inferred [implied] that administrators felt that fraternities would not adhere to University regulations. . .." Freeman went
on to "caution both Mr. Milling and the News-Letter against misquoting interviewees in order to add validity to a specific writer's
opinion. As journalists it is your responsibility to present the facts
First, and most important, the News-Letter has never knowingly
fabricated or distorted facts or quotations within an article. Milling
interviewed Freeman three times for the Phi Mu article; during the
second of these, he confirmed the quotation that Freeman disavowed in his letter. In light of this, Freeman's accusations—that Milling misquoted him and that he did so to support his own view of
the fraternityissue—seem particularly out of place. The News-Letter
stands by Milling's article as fair and correct in its entirety.
'Deliberate Ambiguity'—The February 1991 issue of the Hopkins
Spectator contained an intriguing reference to News-Letter turpitude.
The item appeared in the magazine's Editors' Letter, which discussed
the Uniersity's need for a "conservative voice of dissent" as well
as its overall state of decay. The editors alluded to the University's
recent shuffling of faculty in departments throughout the School of
Arts and Sciences—the product of much backroom academic and
budgetary wrangling—and decried the News-Letter's two recent articles on the subject as "deliberately ambiguous."
There are two possible criticisms here: 1)that the News-Letter was
covering up dirty secrets to help out the administration; 2) that the
issue simply didn't interest the News-Letter enough to elicit good news
coverage. Both implications are false. Even the idea that the News-

Letter was working to protect administrative interests, particularly
when the issue directly affects students and faculty—is pretty close
to hilarious. Staff reporters for our paper consistently have trouble
getting interviews with high-level administrators, and even more difficulty obtaining quotations for the record, because the paper is
perceived as anti-administration. When the suits in Garland want to
bury a story, as a rule, they just keep away from the News-Letter,
hoping that the bright-eyed, bushy-tailed accounts of University prosperity in the Gazette will deflect the attention of prospective and
current students alike.
To the second implication posed in the Spectator—that the story
wasn't considered important by News-Letter editors—we plead not
guilty. The News-Letter spent over a month collecting data and holding
interviews with faculty members to flush out the details of the topsecret numbers involved in the Armstrong-Richardson faculty plan.
We were refused access to any detailed summary of the changes within
Arts and Sciences departments; as aresult, we attempted to build our
own by interviewing the head of every department affected by the
change. Although some of the interviewees were candid about the
measures, many refused comment and others simply failed to return
repeated phone calls. In the end, the data we assembled was not
substantial enough to present a complete—and, we felt, honest—
picture of the numbers involved. The articles that resulted reflected
this omission, but they also gave a sense of how several department
heads were reacting to sharp alterations in departmental budgets. We
encourage the Spectator to publish a full set of figures regarding the
changes if it has access to them—this would be a tremendous service to the Hopkins Community.
Blame not the criminals, but the News-Letter—In a letter to the
editor this week, Director of Security Major Robert Larkin makes
accusations that, while simple on the surface, suggest an ominous
undercurrent. Not surprisingly, the majority of these are directed at
the News-Letter, which has been dogged in its criticism of Hopkins
Security this year. Responding to an editorial last week that pointed
out Security's lapse in preparing the Community Crime Report—a
document that keeps track of off-campus crimes committed against
Hopkins students—Larkin charged that the News-Letter "has regularly
failed to pick up the [Community Crime Report] as they did in the
past." Larkin also blames the News-Letter for community ignorance
about the Hopkins Escort Van service. "I have never read in the
Newsletter [sic] about [the vans]," he wrote, adding that the paper
also "would not print an escort poster we requested to be printed."
Larkin's memory lapse is puzzling. Despite his assertions, the Community Crime Report was first compiled for the News-Letter last fall,
in response to an editorial asking for realistic statistics about crimes
committed off-campus. The only crime report Security had produced regularly in the past is the functional but tedious Campus Crime
Report, a collection of incidents mainly involving thefts from desk
drawers and from gym lockers in the Athletic Center. This data is
not irrelevant, but it is far less important than the Community Crime
Report. If Larkin were as committed to student safety and awareness
as he claims to be, he would resume its compilation immediately.
Larkin's accusation that the News-Letter refused to print an escort
poster is a half-truth. What Larkin was requesting, in effect, was
free advertising space over an indefinite period of time—a privilege
regularly asked of the News-Letter by dozens of other campus
organizations. What the News-Letter offered to do was to run notices
about the escort service, as well as any other relevant Security data,
along with the Community Crime Report—which, as mentioned
before, has not been released once this semester. Larkin has a standing forum in the News-Letter in which to present any information
he feels important to the safety of the Hopkins Community. The NewsLetter provided that space; we did not take it away.

Allen, Midler Star In Mazursky's
Disappointing Scenes From A Mall
by Mark Friedman
Rarely does a film test an audience's patience like Paul
Mazursky's Scenes From a Mall.
Starring Bette Midler and Woody
Allen, this major disappointment
proves that some ideas are better
left ri the dust bin of a filmmaker's mental recesses.
The inconsequential blabber is
all the more startling from
Mazursky, who co-wrote the film
with Roger Simon. Simon and
Mazursky also teamed up on last
year's outstanding Enemies, A
Love Story. Apparently, they've
been living on creative meat
scraps ever since.
Enemies is a thoughtful,
spirited film filled with
cherishable moments. Scenes
From a Mall is just the opposite.
Bland and charmless, Mazursky's
latest makes running up the down
escalator at Owings Mills look
like the most exciting afternoon
imaginable.
Allen is Los Angeles sports
agent Nick Fifer, celebrating his
sixteenth wedding anniversary to
successful pop psychologist
Deborah (Midler). After sending

the kids off to a weekend retreat,
they bubble bathe together and
plan a celebratory dinner party,
only occasionally interrupted by
business calls on their separate
phone lines.
What busy, uninteresting lives
they lead! Aside from the rather
nauseating concept of Midler and
Allen making love, these opening
scenes are lengthy and unrevealing. The actors work well
together, a natural ease evident in
the banter, but the exchanges are
so boring that it makes little difference. Is this what we have to
look forward to in marriage?
Mazursky and Simon establish
the couple's relationship with
such a minimum of enthusiasm
that one is hard pressed to care.
Nick and Deborah are people you
wouldn't want as parents,
spouses, friends, or even pets.
You'd invite them to dinner when
your first choice got the flu.
Nick and Deborah decide to
spend their special day at a mall
in Beverly Hills, exchanging gifts
and buying sushi for the evening's feast. A romantic afternoon
turns sour when Nick admits he's
been having an affair for seven

months. After heated discussions
and marital angst (translation:
Midler does that hysterical thing),
they reach a temporary truce.
Yet Deborah has some secrets
of her own, and later confesses
a fling with a fellow psychiatrist.
Round two of marital hell
follows, with Deborah and Nick
both groping for answers in
another frustrating verbal chase
around the shopping center. The
ending is admirably unsettled
(especially for Touchstone Pictures, kings of the happy ending),
but after enduring the rest of the
film, the audience deserves
better.
The crisis takes place entirely
in the Beverly Hills mall, with
Mazursky and Simon contriving
reason after reason for them to remain there. If you thought a shopping center was a dull setting,
you're right. As if a collapsing
marriage of two whiners weren't
maddening enough, Mazursky's
presentation of the shopping mall
as late twentieth century cultural
context is downright suicideinducing.
Mazursky and Simon aim
several gentle barbs at the L.A.

lifestyles along the way—the car
phones, the traffic, the inescapable, irritating facade of
happiness—but they fall far short
of the mark, Steve Martin's
latest, L.A. Story, is a far more
precise take on this hideous
American subculture.
Much of the problem is Allen.
Pony-tailed and gussied up in
trendy garb, he is unconvincing
from his first moments on screen.
When Allen has acted in the past,
he's been far more effective playing himself—on the opposite
coast. It's a credit to his ability
(and historic lack of self-respect)
that he makes it through the ninety minute film at all.
Nick is forty years old, but
Allen looks like he hasn't been
that young in forty years. Either
the West coast sun has been playing wicked tricks on Nick's face,
or he has progeria, that rapid aging disease. You make the call.
If the story were engaging, the
dialogue witty, or the setting
something other than a shopping
center, Scenes From a Mall might
be worth watching. But it fails on
all three counts. Few films so effectively alienate their audience

from the story.
Films about the complexities of
life are often the best films of all.
Scenes From a Mall is out to give
life a bad name. Instead of spending freely at the mall, Mazursky,

Midler, and Allen ought to be a
little more selective in their purchases. No one is buying it this
time around.

Are The Soul Cages Empty?
by T.H. Kern
Here's the scene: you stand at
the edge of an expanse of
water—an ocean, a gigantic
emerald sea—and in the distance
you see an enormous ship, creeping along the horizon. Big boat,
you think to yourself, awed at the
figure it cuts against the sky. You
wonder if it might be a tanker,
wallowing under the weight of
millions of gallons of oil, or a
cargo ship whose innards have
been stuffed with exotic goods for
a long maritime voyage.
One thing is certain: a ship that
big must be carrying an important payload, something essential
to the welfare of humankind. Not
knowing why, you feel an
allegiance with it, and watch it
skim imperceptibly across the line
between sea and sky.
When the ship is gone—out of
sight, the event concluded—you
look around to see how the world
has changed. Nothing. Everything looks the same. The surface
of the water is vacant, the beach
deserted, the wind still blows
through the whispering palms
overhead. The only thing different is the time: you've spent
an hour fixated on something that
has disappeared without a trace.
That, in short, describes the experience of listening to The Soul
Cages, the latest album by Sting.
Grand in scope, impressively
constructed, and laden with
images of skylines and sailing,
the fourth solo outing by the wellgroomed Gordon Sumner is a
record that sits stubbornly in anchor for almost all of its forty-five
minutes. As it plays, it sounds
coherent, important, even

magical, but after the last song
fades the listener sits there stranded with a feeling of stuffed
hollowness—the emotional
equivalent of a stomach full of
cheese puffs.
It's a surprising result given the
apparent depth of the album. The
Soul Cages is host to a plethora
of recurring images and allusions:
fatherhood, death, the sea, ships,
the cleansing power of water, and

walking in his sleep, he imagines
that he swims out to the ship,
discovers it stuck in irons, and
falls asleep, only to wake as an
ominous gale begins to toss the
vessel on the water.
For the discerning listener who
asks, "So what?" Sting has a
ready reply. Near the end of the
narrative, our hero sees the
"shade of a sailor/On the bridge
through the wheelhouse pane."
But this isn't any ordinary ghost,
for "underneath the sailor's hat,"

In the right hands, this fairly

a rock band. But Sting, with his

Sea," like the majority of The

a tawdry poolside poetry reading.
He lingers wistfully over
syllables, as if contemplating

nature of that public has fundamentally changed. Americans no
longer talk to each other about
ideas, and in that silence, our
public discourse and political
consciousness have withered.
Where our forefathers argued for
hours in the public greens, we are
pacified by 9-second sound-bites
in front of the tube. We have
become spectators of our own
democracy, handing over control
to those politicians that entertain
us most, and keep us thinking the
least.
The situation is not without
hope, however. While our
technology has given us the tools
of our own lobotomization (i.e.
TV news), it has also given us
ways to restart the energetic
dialogue that democracy requires
(i.e. publishing a new book). A
World ofIdeas H is the natural extension of this belief: 29 interviews with an eclectic mix of
thinkers, each of which brings his
own unique perspective to the
problems we face as individuals
and as a society.
Bill Moyers, whose name
could follow the words "this intellectual brought to you by,"
shows himself to be one of the
great askers-of-questions here. As
in his thought-provoking interviews with mythologist Joseph
Campbell, Moyers displays a
remarkable capacity for cutting to
the crucial issues, forcing his subjects into corners, confronting
them with their contradictions,
and evoking their logic and
understanding. In the process,

each subject's world-view is illuminated in all its complexity.
But more impressive than
Moyers himself are the people he
is able to bring to us through
these interviews. Their interests
come from nearly every realm of
human existance, from political
dynamics to philosophies of art to
deep matters of the spirit. They
aren't scholarly bones hiding inside big and hollow language
either; these are people that are
able to articulate their ideas to the
reader with remarkable clarity
and wit. Have a chat with an
ethics professor from the Wharton School of Business, or the

Bill Moyers takes on
the biggest issues of
our time with the
greatest thinkers of
our time
discoverer of the polio vaccine.
Talk to the lyrical poet working
to form a Men's Movement.
Meet the theatre director who set
a production of Don Giovanni in
Harlem and a production of
Shakespeare in a swimming pool.
A World ofIdeas II is a fun and
enlightening read, not because it
gives all the right answers, but
that it asks some of the most
serious questions we face today.
How are we to recapture the interest of citizens in a political
world that no longer seems to respond to them? How are we to

understand our identities in an increasingly multi-cultural environment? What ethical role does the
individual play in a complex
technological world? While
philosophical in nature, these are
also the hottest political topics of
our time—racial conflict, artistic
censorship, abortion rights and
environmental concerns among
them.
These are issues you can find
in any national news magazine
every week, painted there broadly
with ideology and sarcasm. But
what makes this account different
is not only its clarity and intelligence, but its implicit call to
action. This is a book that gets
you somewhere, that manages to
convince you of the most central
of all democratic tenets: that you
can make a difference.
While it could be argued that
29 broad opinions don't make "a
world of ideas," Moyers is
careful never to claim they are.
Rather, for him, these discussions
are a kind of intellectual jumpstart, the initial point of an even
grander and more fruitful
dialogue. He isn't trying to sell
us on his subjects' books, or even
on the ideas they espouse. He is
trying to sell us on the idea of
having ideas in the first place.
And while A World of Ideas 11
may not get hordes of citizens
debating in the public squares, it
may pull us from MTV long
enough to get us talking again. As
Moyers and his subjects make
very clear, there's an awful lot to
talk about.

a wash of literary allusions, all
that lingers is Sting's illusion that
these lyrics are deep and
meaningful.
For all his shortcomings as a
lyricist, however, Sting has
always been a strong composer.
During his tenure with the Police
and throughout his solo career, he
has been a perpetual source of
rich melodies and harmonies, of
hooks that linger in the brain long
after most Top 40 ear candy is
forgotten. His skill as an arranger, particularly on The
Dream of the Blue Turtles, his
first
solo
album,
was
unimpeachable.
It is no surprise, then, that The
Soul Cages contains some exceptional music. What is surprising
is how consistently Sting manages
to dilute it—as well as the band
performing it—in a swarm of
electronic effects. Apparently
tickled with the endless
possibilities of his Synclavier
sampling instrument, he has infested the album with a landscape
of hums and drones which give
the impression that the band
(which includes such talents as
Branford Marsalis, Kenny
Kirkland, and David Sanctious)
is either going to dissolve,
evaporate, or simply be
smothered.
And if much of The Soul Cages
sounds friendly and familiar,
there's a reason: several of the
hooks are cribbed from Police
records. "Mad About You" is a
compendium of snippets from
Synchronicity and Ghost In the
Machine, while "When the
Angels Fall" lifts a slice of
"Every Breath You Take"
piecemeal.
It's
Sting's
prerogative to reuse his own
material, of course, but the songs
that result—like recycled
paper—seem dull and motheaten, despite their perfect sonic
sheen.
The album isn't a total wash.
The first track, "Island of

Souls," is a dreamy 6/4 dirge that
movingly recounts the fantasies
of a young boy whose shipbuilding father is killed in an industrial accident. "All This
Time," the record's first single,
transcends its self-important
lyrics with a joyful, rippling
melody and sharp drumming by
Manu Katche. And "Jeremiah
Blues (Part I)" brings the album
as close to the boiling point as
Sting is likely to get (that is to
say, lukewarm), and gives the
record a much-needed dose of
bite.
The norm for The Soul Cages,
however, is smooth, antiseptic
background music—a blend that
would sound utterly inhuman if
not for Sting's often gargantuan
flights of pretentiousness at the
microphone. When he sings,
regrettably, he enunciates, pressing the syllables, heaving oxygen
into the microphone until he
sounds almost abnormally mannered, as if he were John
Houseman reciting the lyrics of
Def Leppard.
If all this sounds a bit extreme,
it is. The Soul Cages, like both
of the studio albums that preceded it, is yet another product of
Sting's desire to make not merely records, but musical
documents of his thoughts and
feelings. And though he has probably always loved the sound of
his own voice, Sting's singing on
this record threatens—quite
literally—to overpower the
dwindling music behind it.
This would be well and good
if the lyrics here weren't such a
titanic disappointment. But ships
and sails and lost sailors' tales require a sharp ear for cliche and
a good sense of humor, both of
which Sting lacks. With a band
drowned out by the winds of
Synclavier and vocals that belong
in "The Whine of the Ancient
Mariner," The Soul Cages passes
with the air of importance, but
leaves the listener with a sense of
oceanic emptiness.

Rowhouses offer unique offcampus living arrangements, and
like apartment buildings, one can
expect to find the full spectrum
of quality. Some rowhouses are
modern, spacious and immaculately clean, rivaling the
most luxurious of apartments.
Other times, houses can be older,
confining or just plain shabby. In
general, you get what you pay
for, and thus it is important to
shop carefully when selecting a
rowhouse. As a rule of thumb,
rowhouses are slightly cheaper
than apartment buildings.
As houses come in all assortments and varieties, so do
landlords. Some of these
landlords will be extremely personable, helping you with all of
your housing and living needs at
a moment's notice. Others will be
delaying and/or absent-minded,
unknowingly making your living
arrangement a year-long
nightmare. Assessing a landlord
usually requires some prior
knowledge; that is, knowing
someone else who has rented
from a particular landlord before.
If this option is not possible, the
University housing office may
also help steer you toward more

reliable rowhouse options.
Some rowhouses are actual trilevel abodes, accommodating up
to five people. Other rowhouses
are divided into smaller units,
ranging from one-person efficiencies to four-person apartments.
The myths that you need five people to live in a rowhouse setting
are blatantly false.
Things to look for in a
rowhouse are integrity: Is it
visibly damaged anywhere? Will
it stay warm in the winter, and
cool in the summer? Maryland
law requires all houses to have
sufficient heating systems for the
winter months. Does the house
need painting'? Many landlords
will supply paint and supplies,
often free of charge. Security is
another matter to consider. Most
rowhouses have only a durable
lock on their front door. As you
approach Greenmount Avenue to
the east and Twenty-ninth Street
to the south, the risk of crime
becomes greater, while the
average quality and price of the
houses decrease sharply.
Most of the rowhouses that
students rent are in Charles
Village, concentrated upon St.
Paul Street, Calvert Street and

Guilford Avenue. Many find the
walk to campus averaging from
5 to 20 minutes, depending on
where you live. Many houses are
convenient to the 'St. Paul Strip',
which includes Eddie's Supermarket and the Maryland National Bank. The Rotunda, with
its Giant supermarket, lies farther
away (up to three miles). Not all
rowhouses have laundry
machines; some must carry their
clothes to a nearby laundrymat
(the St. Paul Strip has two). This
sometimes poses a great disadvantage to rowhouse living.
All in all, rowhouse living can
be a great and rewarding experience. Their codes and regulations are often less stringent than
apartment buildings; thus, they
potentially can offer more
freedoms. However, rowhouses
can lack the modern conveniences
and efficient service that apartment dwellers take for granted.
Make sure that you have well
checked into all of the aspects of
a rowhouse before signing a
lease. If possible, talk to friends
that now live in rowhouses to get
the full and complete story.

chitecture, and no stage curtains
are used. There are no flat walls
or 90 degree angles; sound waves
tend to diffract randomly in different directions at sharp surfaces. The hall uses a series of 17
seven-foot convex plastic disks
suspended above the stage to
avoid uniform reflection or concentration of sound while
spreading the sound waves from
the stage into the audience.
Over the orchestra seats, 52
concert "clouds," planar structures which help to collect the
sound waves missed by the disks,
disperse sound into the ceiling.
The ceiling then directs the sound
into the audience in much the
same way that a magnifying glass
focuses sunlight.

The design of the Joseph
Meyerhoff Symphony Hall,
located at 1212 Cathedral Street
in downtown Baltimore, retains
a traditional and elegant atmosphere while simultaneously
housing finely tuned acoustics.
The architecture of the
Meyerhoff is constructed to produce a "dead sound," as described by the Manager of Administrations Barbara Kirstel. Usually,
sound waves are absorbed by
obstacles impeding their path.
With dead sound, sound waves
flow around obstacles and continue moving without a break.
To achieve this phenomenon,
the Meyerhoff has a sweeping ar-

The ceiling slopes from 62 feet
high to around 44 feet above the
stage. Sound diffusing baffles line
the walls at various locations.
About 420 tons of plaster, along
with double cylinder block walls,
soundproof the hall from the outside and further reflect internal
sound. No columns were built on
the inside of the building because
of potential interference with
sound waves.
The Meyerhoff is the home of
the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and many other concert
hall performances. It is a rather
new building, completed in 1982.
It is suppOrted both administratively and financially by
the late Joseph Meyerhoff, for
whom the hall is named.

Johns Hopkins researchers
report that caffeine withdrawal
symptoms ranging from headache
and fatigue to muscle pain and
nausea have been found to affect
people intaking lower daily doses
of the popular drug than
previously expected.
A Hopkins team has found that
a 100 milligram dose of caffeine
(i.e. a strong cup of coffee or
three cups of a carbonated
beverage), when taken daily, is
capable of causing withdrawal
symptoms commonly thought only to have plagued heavy users.
Americans consume, on the
average, 211 milligrams of caffeine a day.
Caffeine withdrawal has been
recognized as a phenomenon at
high doses. "I think that general
literature would have suggested
that people consuming high doses
of caffeine would have been
caffeine
vulnerable
to

withdrawal," notes Dr. Roland
R. Griffiths, professor of
psychiatry and neuroscience.
"Our studies showed that low
doses of caffeine were enough to
produce withdrawal. . .People
would not have thought that a
great proportion of the population
was at risk of experiencing it."
In the first part of the experiment, seven subjects were given
100 milligrams of caffeine a day.
A placebo (substance which looks
like caffeine but is not) was then
intermittently substituted for 12
days without the subject's
knowledge. Withdrawal effects
peaked at days one and two and
then decreased, lasting for as long
as a week.
In the second part of the experiment, the magnitude of
withdrawal symptoms in comparison to caffeine dosages was
investigated as 17 subjects were
maintained at 100, 300, or 600
milligrams of capsulated caffeine
a day. Headache magnitudes

were found to be significantly
higher at the 600 milligram
dosage than at the 100 milligram
dosage.
The withdrawal symptoms for
both experiments were associated
with increasing ratings of
headache, drowsiness, and
decreased ratings of energy.
Other symptoms that were found
were not expected. "Headache
and fatigue were primary
symptoms—we had known that
before. But in addition to that, we
saw muscle pain and stiffness. . .
flu-like symptoms, nausea and
occasional vomiting," Griffiths
explained.
According to Griffiths, "There
are a lot of questions that remain," such as the minimum caffeine exposure and how long it
takes to wash out caffeine sensitivity. In the future, Griffiths
hopes to find what proportion of
the population is at risk for experiencing caffeine withdrawal,
and to what extent.

Women's
Fencing
Improved
by Jessica Rosenbaum
The women's fencing team
travelled to Navy for a dual meet
and lost 11-5 on Saturday,
February 16. However, the
women fencers were fairly happy with this result because last
year Navy completely sweeped
the meet. The team has a season
record of three wins and two
losses.
Ruth Ochia said, "Traditionally we lost to Navy, but this year
we did better than expected. We
lost four of our matches with a
5-4 record. We were very close
to winning many of them and
most of the other matches were
fairly close also."
Coach Gary Green agreed,
"We lost by just one touch in four
of our matches and if we had won
those, we would have won the
match. In that sense, it was a
disappointing match for us."
He added, "We definitely
fenced better in this match than
in previous years which indicates
the strength of the current team.
Our win-loss record is also one
of the best in recent years."
In individual competition,
Laura Greenwald won three of
her four matches. Coach Green
was very pleased with her performance. "She was very impressive and she is only a
sophomore. She has a distinctive
style that challenges her opponents and was very effective on
Saturday," he said.
"The rest of the team also does
well. They each have good days
and not so good days," added
assistant coach Anna Lisa
Cataldo.
Ruth Ochia and Yuri Saito contributed to the team's effort by
each winning a match. Erica
Roulier and Keiko Akasofu also
competed against Navy.
This weekend, six members of
the team will travel to Cleveland
for the UAA championships. The
team will also compete in the National A Intercollegiate Women's
Fencing Association Championships in New York before ending
its season.

For the second consecutive
season, the Johns Hopkins
women's basketball team lost to
host Moravian in the first round
of the MAC playoffs. Unlike last
season's last second win,
however, the Lady Greyhounds,
ranked sixth in the nation, raced
to a 92-61 victory behind AllAmerica candidate Kathy Beck's
24 points and 11 rebounds.
The Lady Jays started off well,
jumping out to a 4-0 lead, but it
was all downhill from there.
Moravian scored its first points
on a three-pointer by Monica
Deeb. The Lady Greyhounds
would go on to score 24 points on
three-pointers, compared to none
for Hopkins.

paid its dividends, leading to a
ten-point lead early in the first
half. Hopkins was out of sync
for the remainder of the game, as
they were forced to play catch-up
against a team riding a 21-game
winning streak.

Shoveling through the Mail
Through the years, and particularly during this year, the NewsLetter has received hundreds of thoughtful, often provocative letters. Their missions are various: some take a stand on campus issues;
some respond to opinion pieces or other letters; some warn of growing conspiracies in American politics; and others, rare though they
are, take the News-Letter to task for its journalistic practices. The
News-Letter reads this last group with intense interest and sincere
concern. Like most publications, we rely upon our readers to bring
things to our attention that slip through editorial cracks: evidence
of racism or sexism, misquotes or incorrect attribution of quotes,
editorializing in stories, pertinent isues that repeatedly fail to receive
coverage in our pages—the list is potentially infinite. Although errors inevitably do wriggle their way into each issue, the News-Letter
tries assiduously each week to publish a paper that fairly represents
both life at Johns Hopkins and the concerns of the Hopkins Community. Thus we are grateful for these corrections and clarifications;
they remind us that every story has unexplored angles, issues that
do not automatically float to the surface.
Sometimes, however, the News-Letter hears from readers who have
more sweeping accusations to make. Their letters might accuse us
of doing damage to the University's reputation—or perhaps to an individual's—or of intentionally burying stories that the Hopkins Community has a right to know about. These are seious accusations, stabs
that call into question everything that the News-Letter requires to
operate successfully—the trust of its readers and the belief that the
paper serves an important function. Recently, three such complaints
have been leveled at the News-Letter, two in letters to the editors
and one in a commentary printed in the Hopkins Spectator. Each
deserves a response.
'Misquoting'—In the February 15 issue of the News-Letter, there
appeared a letter to the editors by Craig Freeman, who accused staff
reporter Harry Milling of "severely misquoting" him in a February
8 article about Phi Mu's opportunity to move into Rogers House.
The quotation at issue was Freeman's statement that some administrators believed that "a fraternity's occupation of Rogers House
might not 'run as smoothly' as a sorority's occupation might." This,
Freeman said, "inferred [implied] that administrators felt that fraternities would not adhere to University regulations. . .." Freeman went
on to "caution both Mr. Milling and the News-Letter against misquoting interviewees in order to add validity to a specific writer's
opinion. As journalists it is your responsibility to present the facts
First, and most important, the News-Letter has never knowingly
fabricated or distorted facts or quotations within an article. Milling
interviewed Freeman three times for the Phi Mu article; during the
second of these, he confirmed the quotation that Freeman disavowed in his letter. In light of this, Freeman's accusations—that Milling misquoted him and that he did so to support his own view of
the fraternityissue—seem particularly out of place. The News-Letter
stands by Milling's article as fair and correct in its entirety.
'Deliberate Ambiguity'—The February 1991 issue of the Hopkins
Spectator contained an intriguing reference to News-Letter turpitude.
The item appeared in the magazine's Editors' Letter, which discussed
the Uniersity's need for a "conservative voice of dissent" as well
as its overall state of decay. The editors alluded to the University's
recent shuffling of faculty in departments throughout the School of
Arts and Sciences—the product of much backroom academic and
budgetary wrangling—and decried the News-Letter's two recent articles on the subject as "deliberately ambiguous."
There are two possible criticisms here: 1)that the News-Letter was
covering up dirty secrets to help out the administration; 2) that the
issue simply didn't interest the News-Letter enough to elicit good news
coverage. Both implications are false. Even the idea that the News-

Letter was working to protect administrative interests, particularly
when the issue directly affects students and faculty—is pretty close
to hilarious. Staff reporters for our paper consistently have trouble
getting interviews with high-level administrators, and even more difficulty obtaining quotations for the record, because the paper is
perceived as anti-administration. When the suits in Garland want to
bury a story, as a rule, they just keep away from the News-Letter,
hoping that the bright-eyed, bushy-tailed accounts of University prosperity in the Gazette will deflect the attention of prospective and
current students alike.
To the second implication posed in the Spectator—that the story
wasn't considered important by News-Letter editors—we plead not
guilty. The News-Letter spent over a month collecting data and holding
interviews with faculty members to flush out the details of the topsecret numbers involved in the Armstrong-Richardson faculty plan.
We were refused access to any detailed summary of the changes within
Arts and Sciences departments; as aresult, we attempted to build our
own by interviewing the head of every department affected by the
change. Although some of the interviewees were candid about the
measures, many refused comment and others simply failed to return
repeated phone calls. In the end, the data we assembled was not
substantial enough to present a complete—and, we felt, honest—
picture of the numbers involved. The articles that resulted reflected
this omission, but they also gave a sense of how several department
heads were reacting to sharp alterations in departmental budgets. We
encourage the Spectator to publish a full set of figures regarding the
changes if it has access to them—this would be a tremendous service to the Hopkins Community.
Blame not the criminals, but the News-Letter—In a letter to the
editor this week, Director of Security Major Robert Larkin makes
accusations that, while simple on the surface, suggest an ominous
undercurrent. Not surprisingly, the majority of these are directed at
the News-Letter, which has been dogged in its criticism of Hopkins
Security this year. Responding to an editorial last week that pointed
out Security's lapse in preparing the Community Crime Report—a
document that keeps track of off-campus crimes committed against
Hopkins students—Larkin charged that the News-Letter "has regularly
failed to pick up the [Community Crime Report] as they did in the
past." Larkin also blames the News-Letter for community ignorance
about the Hopkins Escort Van service. "I have never read in the
Newsletter [sic] about [the vans]," he wrote, adding that the paper

Allen, Midler Star In Mazursky's
Disappointing Scenes From A Mall
by Mark Friedman
Rarely does a film test an audience's patience like Paul
Mazursky's Scenes From a Mall.
Starring Bette Midler and Woody
Allen, this major disappointment
proves that some ideas are better
left ri the dust bin of a filmmaker's mental recesses.
The inconsequential blabber is
all the more startling from
Mazursky, who co-wrote the film
with Roger Simon. Simon and
Mazursky also teamed up on last
year's outstanding Enemies, A
Love Story. Apparently, they've
been living on creative meat
scraps ever since.
Enemies is a thoughtful,
spirited film filled with
cherishable moments. Scenes
From a Mall is just the opposite.
Bland and charmless, Mazursky's
latest makes running up the down
escalator at Owings Mills look
like the most exciting afternoon
imaginable.
Allen is Los Angeles sports
agent Nick Fifer, celebrating his
sixteenth wedding anniversary to
successful pop psychologist
Deborah (Midler). After sending

the kids off to a weekend retreat,
they bubble bathe together and
plan a celebratory dinner party,
only occasionally interrupted by
business calls on their separate
phone lines.
What busy, uninteresting lives
they lead! Aside from the rather
nauseating concept of Midler and
Allen making love, these opening
scenes are lengthy and unrevealing. The actors work well
together, a natural ease evident in
the banter, but the exchanges are
so boring that it makes little difference. Is this what we have to
look forward to in marriage?
Mazursky and Simon establish
the couple's relationship with
such a minimum of enthusiasm
that one is hard pressed to care.
Nick and Deborah are people you
wouldn't want as parents,
spouses, friends, or even pets.
You'd invite them to dinner when
your first choice got the flu.
Nick and Deborah decide to
spend their special day at a mall
in Beverly Hills, exchanging gifts
and buying sushi for the evening's feast. A romantic afternoon
turns sour when Nick admits he's
been having an affair for seven

months. After heated discussions
and marital angst (translation:
Midler does that hysterical thing),
they reach a temporary truce.
Yet Deborah has some secrets
of her own, and later confesses
a fling with a fellow psychiatrist.
Round two of marital hell
follows, with Deborah and Nick
both groping for answers in
another frustrating verbal chase
around the shopping center. The
ending is admirably unsettled
(especially for Touchstone Pictures, kings of the happy ending),
but after enduring the rest of the
film, the audience deserves
better.
The crisis takes place entirely
in the Beverly Hills mall, with
Mazursky and Simon contriving
reason after reason for them to remain there. If you thought a shopping center was a dull setting,
you're right. As if a collapsing
marriage of two whiners weren't
maddening enough, Mazursky's
presentation of the shopping mall
as late twentieth century cultural
context is downright suicideinducing.
Mazursky and Simon aim
several gentle barbs at the L.A.

lifestyles along the way—the car
phones, the traffic, the inescapable, irritating facade of
happiness—but they fall far short
of the mark, Steve Martin's
latest, L.A. Story, is a far more
precise take on this hideous
American subculture.
Much of the problem is Allen.
Pony-tailed and gussied up in
trendy garb, he is unconvincing
from his first moments on screen.
When Allen has acted in the past,
he's been far more effective playing himself—on the opposite
coast. It's a credit to his ability
(and historic lack of self-respect)
that he makes it through the ninety minute film at all.
Nick is forty years old, but
Allen looks like he hasn't been
that young in forty years. Either
the West coast sun has been playing wicked tricks on Nick's face,
or he has progeria, that rapid aging disease. You make the call.
If the story were engaging, the
dialogue witty, or the setting
something other than a shopping
center, Scenes From a Mall might
be worth watching. But it fails on
all three counts. Few films so effectively alienate their audience

infidelities in Scenes From A Mall.

from the story.
Films about the complexities of
life are often the best films of all.
Scenes From a Mall is out to give
life a bad name. Instead of spending freely at the mall, Mazursky,

Midler, and Allen ought to be a
little more selective in their purchases. No one is buying it this
time around.

Are The Soul Cages Empty?
by T.H. Kern
Here's the scene: you stand at
the edge of an expanse of
water—an ocean, a gigantic
emerald sea—and in the distance
you see an enormous ship, creeping along the horizon. Big boat,
you think to yourself, awed at the
figure it cuts against the sky. You
wonder if it might be a tanker,
wallowing under the weight of
millions of gallons of oil, or a
cargo ship whose innards have
been stuffed with exotic goods for
a long maritime voyage.
One thing is certain: a ship that
big must be carrying an important payload, something essential
to the welfare of humankind. Not
knowing why, you feel an
allegiance with it, and watch it
skim imperceptibly across the line
between sea and sky.
When the ship is gone—out of
sight, the event concluded—you
look around to see how the world
has changed. Nothing. Everything looks the same. The surface
of the water is vacant, the beach
deserted, the wind still blows
through the whispering palms
overhead. The only thing different is the time: you've spent
an hour fixated on something that
has disappeared without a trace.
That, in short, describes the experience of listening to The Soul
Cages, the latest album by Sting.
Grand in scope, impressively
constructed, and laden with
images of skylines and sailing,
the fourth solo outing by the wellgroomed Gordon Sumner is a
record that sits stubbornly in anchor for almost all of its forty-five
minutes. As it plays, it sounds
coherent, important, even

magical, but after the last song
fades the listener sits there stranded with a feeling of stuffed
hollowness—the emotional
equivalent of a stomach full of
cheese puffs.
It's a surprising result given the
apparent depth of the album. The
Soul Cages is host to a plethora
of recurring images and allusions:
fatherhood, death, the sea, ships,
the cleansing power of water, and
others. It's a catalog with an
undeniable literary pedigree, rich
with romantic associations of
hardship and courage, and Sting

The Soul Cages
finds Sting in new
and often
ridiculous form.
injects them liberally into his
material. "The Wild Wild Sea"
recounts an episode in which the
narrator one day sees a ship on
the horizon that sporadically appears and disappears. That night,
walking in his sleep, he imagines
that he swims out to the ship,
discovers it stuck in irons, and
falls asleep, only to wake as an
ominous gale begins to toss the
vessel on the water.
For the discerning listener who
asks, "So what?" Sting has a
ready reply. Near the end of the
narrative, our hero sees the
"shade of a sailor/On the bridge
through the wheelhouse pane."
But this isn't any ordinary ghost,
for "underneath the sailor's hat,"

he reveals after a melodramatic
pause, "I saw my father's face."
In the right hands, this fairly
conventional narrative could
perhaps survive a performance by
a rock band. But Sting, with his
perennial love for the highfalutin, turns "The Wild Wild
Sea," like the majority of The
Soul Cages, into little more than
a tawdry poolside poetry reading.
He lingers wistfully over
syllables, as if contemplating
issues of profound philosophical
import, and delivers completely
maudlin lines ("All around me
was silence/As if mocking my
frail human hopes") as if they
were scripture—or poetry, for
that matter.
Though Sting has made no
secret of his poetic aspirations
over the years (his last album,
...Nothing Like the Sun,took its
title from a Shakespearean sonnet), The Soul Cages finds him in
new and often ridiculous form.
The majority of songs here are
written in rigid meter, with accompanying rhyme schemes that
might flow nicely if Sting weren't
so intent on letting the listener
know—by singing in halting
phrases—how "well structured"
they are.
He has an affection for lofty
sounding words and phrases: people in these songs don't walk in
their sleep, but in their
"slumber"; there are no ghosts
on this record, but "shades."
Gone is the subtlety that made
many of the Police's albums so
engaging, and left in its place is
Sting who, despite an occasional
apt phrase, now merely acts as if

by Paul Kramer
If you've ever stayed up all
night arguing if God is dead, if
democracy is really possible, or
if it's nature or nurture that makes
boys seem different from girls,
then you need to get hold of a
copy of A World of Ideas II. In
his second volume, Bill Moyers
takes on the biggest issues of our
time with, not surprisingly, some
of the greatest thinkers of our
time.
In his introduction, Moyers
describes the history of
democracy as the history of a particular kind of conversation. In
early America, the printing press
produced a community whose
central feature was common
news, and whose dialogues and
debates, in taverns and public
squares, allowed our young
democracy to work. The news
provided the underlying social
fabric of the American public,
and the press's most important
task was to take that public
seriously.
But, according to Moyers, the
nature of that public has fundamentally changed. Americans no
longer talk to each other about
ideas, and in that silence, our
public discourse and political
consciousness have withered.
Where our forefathers argued for
hours in the public greens, we are
pacified by 9-second sound-bites
in front of the tube. We have
become spectators of our own
democracy, handing over control
to those politicians that entertain
us most, and keep us thinking the
least.
The situation is not without
hope, however. While our
technology has given us the tools
of our own lobotomization (i.e.
TV news), it has also given us
ways to restart the energetic
dialogue that democracy requires
(i.e. publishing a new book). A
World ofIdeas H is the natural extension of this belief: 29 interviews with an eclectic mix of
thinkers, each of which brings his
own unique perspective to the
problems we face as individuals
and as a society.
Bill Moyers, whose name
could follow the words "this intellectual brought to you by,"
shows himself to be one of the
great askers-of-questions here. As
in his thought-provoking interviews with mythologist Joseph
Campbell, Moyers displays a
remarkable capacity for cutting to
the crucial issues, forcing his subjects into corners, confronting
them with their contradictions,
and evoking their logic and
understanding. In the process,

each subject's world-view is illuminated in all its complexity.
But more impressive than
Moyers himself are the people he
is able to bring to us through
these interviews. Their interests
come from nearly every realm of
human existance, from political
dynamics to philosophies of art to
deep matters of the spirit. They
aren't scholarly bones hiding inside big and hollow language
either; these are people that are
able to articulate their ideas to the
reader with remarkable clarity
and wit. Have a chat with an
ethics professor from the Wharton School of Business, or the

Bill Moyers takes on
the biggest issues of
our time with the
greatest thinkers of
our time
discoverer of the polio vaccine.
Talk to the lyrical poet working
to form a Men's Movement.
Meet the theatre director who set
a production of Don Giovanni in
Harlem and a production of
Shakespeare in a swimming pool.
A World ofIdeas II is a fun and
enlightening read, not because it
gives all the right answers, but
that it asks some of the most
serious questions we face today.
How are we to recapture the interest of citizens in a political
world that no longer seems to respond to them? How are we to

understand our identities in an increasingly multi-cultural environment? What ethical role does the
individual play in a complex
technological world? While
philosophical in nature, these are
also the hottest political topics of
our time—racial conflict, artistic
censorship, abortion rights and
environmental concerns among
them.
These are issues you can find
in any national news magazine
every week, painted there broadly
with ideology and sarcasm. But
what makes this account different
is not only its clarity and intelligence, but its implicit call to
action. This is a book that gets
you somewhere, that manages to
convince you of the most central
of all democratic tenets: that you
can make a difference.
While it could be argued that
29 broad opinions don't make "a
world of ideas," Moyers is
careful never to claim they are.
Rather, for him, these discussions
are a kind of intellectual jumpstart, the initial point of an even
grander and more fruitful
dialogue. He isn't trying to sell
us on his subjects' books, or even
on the ideas they espouse. He is
trying to sell us on the idea of
having ideas in the first place.
And while A World of Ideas 11
may not get hordes of citizens
debating in the public squares, it
may pull us from MTV long
enough to get us talking again. As
Moyers and his subjects make
very clear, there's an awful lot to
talk about.

a wash of literary allusions, all
that lingers is Sting's illusion that
these lyrics are deep and
meaningful.
For all his shortcomings as a
lyricist, however, Sting has
always been a strong composer.
During his tenure with the Police
and throughout his solo career, he
has been a perpetual source of
rich melodies and harmonies, of
hooks that linger in the brain long
after most Top 40 ear candy is
forgotten. His skill as an arranger, particularly on The
Dream of the Blue Turtles, his
first
solo
album,
was
unimpeachable.
It is no surprise, then, that The
Soul Cages contains some exceptional music. What is surprising
is how consistently Sting manages
to dilute it—as well as the band
performing it—in a swarm of
electronic effects. Apparently
tickled with the endless
possibilities of his Synclavier
sampling instrument, he has infested the album with a landscape
of hums and drones which give
the impression that the band
(which includes such talents as
Branford Marsalis, Kenny
Kirkland, and David Sanctious)
is either going to dissolve,
evaporate, or simply be
smothered.
And if much of The Soul Cages
sounds friendly and familiar,
there's a reason: several of the
hooks are cribbed from Police
records. "Mad About You" is a
compendium of snippets from
Synchronicity and Ghost In the
Machine, while "When the
Angels Fall" lifts a slice of
"Every Breath You Take"
piecemeal.
It's
Sting's
prerogative to reuse his own
material, of course, but the songs
that result—like recycled
paper—seem dull and motheaten, despite their perfect sonic
sheen.
The album isn't a total wash.
The first track, "Island of

Souls," is a dreamy 6/4 dirge that
movingly recounts the fantasies
of a young boy whose shipbuilding father is killed in an industrial accident. "All This
Time," the record's first single,
transcends its self-important
lyrics with a joyful, rippling
melody and sharp drumming by
Manu Katche. And "Jeremiah
Blues (Part I)" brings the album
as close to the boiling point as
Sting is likely to get (that is to
say, lukewarm), and gives the
record a much-needed dose of
bite.
The norm for The Soul Cages,
however, is smooth, antiseptic
background music—a blend that
would sound utterly inhuman if
not for Sting's often gargantuan
flights of pretentiousness at the
microphone. When he sings,
regrettably, he enunciates, pressing the syllables, heaving oxygen
into the microphone until he
sounds almost abnormally mannered, as if he were John
Houseman reciting the lyrics of
Def Leppard.
If all this sounds a bit extreme,
it is. The Soul Cages, like both
of the studio albums that preceded it, is yet another product of
Sting's desire to make not merely records, but musical
documents of his thoughts and
feelings. And though he has probably always loved the sound of
his own voice, Sting's singing on
this record threatens—quite
literally—to overpower the
dwindling music behind it.
This would be well and good
if the lyrics here weren't such a
titanic disappointment. But ships
and sails and lost sailors' tales require a sharp ear for cliche and
a good sense of humor, both of
which Sting lacks. With a band
drowned out by the winds of
Synclavier and vocals that belong
in "The Whine of the Ancient
Mariner," The Soul Cages passes
with the air of importance, but
leaves the listener with a sense of
oceanic emptiness.

Donna Williamson

Doreen Patron

Rowhouses offer unique offcampus living arrangements, and
like apartment buildings, one can
expect to find the full spectrum
of quality. Some rowhouses are
modern, spacious and immaculately clean, rivaling the
most luxurious of apartments.
Other times, houses can be older,
confining or just plain shabby. In
general, you get what you pay
for, and thus it is important to
shop carefully when selecting a
rowhouse. As a rule of thumb,
rowhouses are slightly cheaper
than apartment buildings.
As houses come in all assortments and varieties, so do
landlords. Some of these
landlords will be extremely personable, helping you with all of
your housing and living needs at
a moment's notice. Others will be
delaying and/or absent-minded,
unknowingly making your living
arrangement a year-long
nightmare. Assessing a landlord
usually requires some prior
knowledge; that is, knowing
someone else who has rented
from a particular landlord before.
If this option is not possible, the
University housing office may
also help steer you toward more

reliable rowhouse options.
Some rowhouses are actual trilevel abodes, accommodating up
to five people. Other rowhouses
are divided into smaller units,
ranging from one-person efficiencies to four-person apartments.
The myths that you need five people to live in a rowhouse setting
are blatantly false.
Things to look for in a
rowhouse are integrity: Is it
visibly damaged anywhere? Will
it stay warm in the winter, and
cool in the summer? Maryland
law requires all houses to have
sufficient heating systems for the
winter months. Does the house
need painting'? Many landlords
will supply paint and supplies,
often free of charge. Security is
another matter to consider. Most
rowhouses have only a durable
lock on their front door. As you
approach Greenmount Avenue to
the east and Twenty-ninth Street
to the south, the risk of crime
becomes greater, while the
average quality and price of the
houses decrease sharply.
Most of the rowhouses that
students rent are in Charles
Village, concentrated upon St.
Paul Street, Calvert Street and

Guilford Avenue. Many find the
walk to campus averaging from
5 to 20 minutes, depending on
where you live. Many houses are
convenient to the 'St. Paul Strip',
which includes Eddie's Supermarket and the Maryland National Bank. The Rotunda, with
its Giant supermarket, lies farther
away (up to three miles). Not all
rowhouses have laundry
machines; some must carry their
clothes to a nearby laundrymat
(the St. Paul Strip has two). This
sometimes poses a great disadvantage to rowhouse living.
All in all, rowhouse living can
be a great and rewarding experience. Their codes and regulations are often less stringent than
apartment buildings; thus, they
potentially can offer more
freedoms. However, rowhouses
can lack the modern conveniences
and efficient service that apartment dwellers take for granted.
Make sure that you have well
checked into all of the aspects of
a rowhouse before signing a
lease. If possible, talk to friends
that now live in rowhouses to get
the full and complete story.

Despite their sodden appearance both inside and out, the
Homewood Apartments offer a
number of attractive features.
First among these is size: the
apartments are very spacious,
some surprisingly so, with high
ceilings to match. Second is location: perched on the corner of
Charles and 31st Sts., the
building is close to campus but
isolated from a lot of the chaos
of 33rd St. Third is maintenance:
Quick to respond and more
thorough than you would ever expect from an institutional labor
pool, the University maintenance
crew does a friendly and
workmanlike job.
That's the good side of things;
what about the bad? Well, apartments come unfurnished, the
Homewood deals in 12-month
leases only, and prices tend to be
higher than at other locations,
especially non-University dwellings. Rents for 1990-91 were: for
an efficiency, $390 per month;
for a one-bedroom shared by two
people, $217.50 per month per
person; for a two-bedroom, $225
per month per person; for a threebedroom, $250 per month per
person. All utilities and
maintenance service are included, unless you operate an air conditioner, for which a nominal fee
is charged monthly. Rental prices
next year will probably be from
8 to 10 percent higher.
The front of this gigantic
building faces the small, but
decidedly verdant park across
Charles St. and also offers a nice
view of the Art Museum (Violins,
Violence, Silence). Those left
with views of the rear can enjoy
the everyday spectacle of
Lovegrove Ave.: dumpsters,
homeless people, weather beaten

St. Paul Court, conveniently
located across from Eddie's and

business district, offers close and
pleasant accomodations. A sortof Spanish design with a stucco
exterior, the building looks pretty damn neat.
The apartments inside are
clean, well-kept, and repainted
between tenants. As an older
building, the structure has been
renovated over the years, and
sometimes that has resulted in
oddly shaped apartments. Additionally, there is no single
floorplan, but manager Cora
Price Townes, will be happy to
show you several different spaces
for your needs.
The rent is a variable. For an
individual, it can be high—as
much as $425 a month for a
"junior" (smaller than a one
bedroom). But a two bedroom,
which can comfortably accommodate four people, is around
$900 a month, more in line with

centrally), hot and cold water,

on the fire escape Mon., Wed.,
or Fri.)

living in St. Paul Court, including
the eponymous courtyard, which
has a gazebo, flower beds,
several benches, and a fountain
for reading or relaxing in warmer
weather. The close proximity to
campus is a plus, as is the quiet
atmosphere. The office will accept large parcels and UPS

chitecture, and no stage curtains
are used. There are no flat walls
or 90 degree angles; sound waves
tend to diffract randomly in different directions at sharp surfaces. The hall uses a series of 17
seven-foot convex plastic disks
suspended above the stage to
avoid uniform reflection or concentration of sound while
spreading the sound waves from
the stage into the audience.
Over the orchestra seats, 52
concert "clouds," planar structures which help to collect the
sound waves missed by the disks,
disperse sound into the ceiling.
The ceiling then directs the sound
into the audience in much the
same way that a magnifying glass
focuses sunlight.

The design of the Joseph
Meyerhoff Symphony Hall,
located at 1212 Cathedral Street
in downtown Baltimore, retains
a traditional and elegant atmosphere while simultaneously
housing finely tuned acoustics.
The architecture of the
Meyerhoff is constructed to produce a "dead sound," as described by the Manager of Administrations Barbara Kirstel. Usually,
sound waves are absorbed by
obstacles impeding their path.
With dead sound, sound waves
flow around obstacles and continue moving without a break.
To achieve this phenomenon,
the Meyerhoff has a sweeping ar-

The ceiling slopes from 62 feet
high to around 44 feet above the
stage. Sound diffusing baffles line
the walls at various locations.
About 420 tons of plaster, along
with double cylinder block walls,
soundproof the hall from the outside and further reflect internal
sound. No columns were built on
the inside of the building because
of potential interference with
sound waves.
The Meyerhoff is the home of
the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and many other concert
hall performances. It is a rather
new building, completed in 1982.
It is suppOrted both administratively and financially by
the late Joseph Meyerhoff, for
whom the hall is named.

Johns Hopkins researchers
report that caffeine withdrawal
symptoms ranging from headache
and fatigue to muscle pain and
nausea have been found to affect
people intaking lower daily doses
of the popular drug than
previously expected.
A Hopkins team has found that
a 100 milligram dose of caffeine
(i.e. a strong cup of coffee or
three cups of a carbonated
beverage), when taken daily, is
capable of causing withdrawal
symptoms commonly thought only to have plagued heavy users.
Americans consume, on the
average, 211 milligrams of caffeine a day.
Caffeine withdrawal has been
recognized as a phenomenon at
high doses. "I think that general
literature would have suggested
that people consuming high doses
of caffeine would have been
caffeine
vulnerable
to

withdrawal," notes Dr. Roland
R. Griffiths, professor of
psychiatry and neuroscience.
"Our studies showed that low
doses of caffeine were enough to
produce withdrawal. . .People
would not have thought that a
great proportion of the population
was at risk of experiencing it."
In the first part of the experiment, seven subjects were given
100 milligrams of caffeine a day.
A placebo (substance which looks
like caffeine but is not) was then
intermittently substituted for 12
days without the subject's
knowledge. Withdrawal effects
peaked at days one and two and
then decreased, lasting for as long
as a week.
In the second part of the experiment, the magnitude of
withdrawal symptoms in comparison to caffeine dosages was
investigated as 17 subjects were
maintained at 100, 300, or 600
milligrams of capsulated caffeine
a day. Headache magnitudes

were found to be significantly
higher at the 600 milligram
dosage than at the 100 milligram
dosage.
The withdrawal symptoms for
both experiments were associated
with increasing ratings of
headache, drowsiness, and
decreased ratings of energy.
Other symptoms that were found
were not expected. "Headache
and fatigue were primary
symptoms—we had known that
before. But in addition to that, we
saw muscle pain and stiffness. . .
flu-like symptoms, nausea and
occasional vomiting," Griffiths
explained.
According to Griffiths, "There
are a lot of questions that remain," such as the minimum caffeine exposure and how long it
takes to wash out caffeine sensitivity. In the future, Griffiths
hopes to find what proportion of
the population is at risk for experiencing caffeine withdrawal,
and to what extent.

Women's
Fencing
Improved
by Jessica Rosenbaum
The women's fencing team
travelled to Navy for a dual meet
and lost 11-5 on Saturday,
February 16. However, the
women fencers were fairly happy with this result because last
year Navy completely sweeped
the meet. The team has a season
record of three wins and two
losses.
Ruth Ochia said, "Traditionally we lost to Navy, but this year
we did better than expected. We
lost four of our matches with a
5-4 record. We were very close
to winning many of them and
most of the other matches were
fairly close also."
Coach Gary Green agreed,
"We lost by just one touch in four
of our matches and if we had won
those, we would have won the
match. In that sense, it was a
disappointing match for us."
He added, "We definitely
fenced better in this match than
in previous years which indicates
the strength of the current team.
Our win-loss record is also one
of the best in recent years."
In individual competition,
Laura Greenwald won three of
her four matches. Coach Green
was very pleased with her performance. "She was very impressive and she is only a
sophomore. She has a distinctive
style that challenges her opponents and was very effective on
Saturday," he said.
"The rest of the team also does
well. They each have good days
and not so good days," added
assistant coach Anna Lisa
Cataldo.
Ruth Ochia and Yuri Saito contributed to the team's effort by
each winning a match. Erica
Roulier and Keiko Akasofu also
competed against Navy.
This weekend, six members of
the team will travel to Cleveland
for the UAA championships. The
team will also compete in the National A Intercollegiate Women's
Fencing Association Championships in New York before ending
its season.

season, the Johns Hopkins
women's basketball team lost to
host Moravian in the first round
of the MAC playoffs. Unlike last
season's last second win,
however, the Lady Greyhounds,
ranked sixth in the nation, raced
to a 92-61 victory behind AllAmerica candidate Kathy Beck's
24 points and 11 rebounds.
The Lady Jays started off well,
jumping out to a 4-0 lead, but it
was all downhill from there.
Moravian scored its first points
on a three-pointer by Monica
Deeb. The Lady Greyhounds
would go on to score 24 points on
three-pointers, compared to none
for Hopkins.

paid its dividends, leading to a
ten-point lead early in the first
half. Hopkins was out of sync
for the remainder of the game, as
they were forced to play catch-up
against a team riding a 21-game
winning streak.
